page.title: 08History of Morchard Bishop-2
page.content: The remains of the village pound on Polson Hill dates from the 15th century and is now maintained as a feature by the gardening club. In Fore Street is reputedly the longest continuous row of thatched cottages in Devon.These were built between 1790 and 1810 on land which was part of waste ground forming the centre of,originally,a typical Anglo- Saxon village layout. The first village school was started in 1733 with money left by Thomasine Tucker,for 16 poor children.They were dressed in blue and provided with a Bible.The original building is now a bungalow,the present school was built by the Church of England in 1872 at a cost of Â£2000 for 280 children.It has in recent years been enlarged to include a kitchen and hall.There are now 115 pupils and 5 staff.
